Being falsley accused of child abuse is awful. But worse than abuse itself, or being shaken to death? I think not.  Perhaps you've never actually seen what we call "broken babies" in the hospital world ... I promise it is worse than what turns out to be an incorrect (versus false) accusation.

It's always good when we take  pause from the more educated in our society.  I say prove it, too many well educated, well spoken people have been wrong and the media just runs with it.  This is no different from the Salem Witch Trials.  The more educated in our society should be more educated.

While I agree that like with most things, care must be taken, the last sentence in your comment is very inflammatory. I would say that getting murdered or beaten so badly you are severely brain damaged for life and unable to care for yourself, is objectively worse than being wrongly accused of a crime. When it occurs to children, we cloak it in the euphemism of "abuse," when we really need to call it for what it is- murder and devastating injuries, if done to an adult.

As one who has worked as an attorney, a judge, and as a guardian ad litem for neglected and abused children in the courts, I was often surprised at the tenuous or absent connection between the injury(-ies) sustained  by the child in the case and he actions of the parent(s) or person(s) charged with the child's abuse and/or neglect.  Causation did not seem to present much of a problem for prosecutors, police, jurors, the press, etc., who seemed very quick to assign blame for a child's injury, whether or not the parent had actually acted or failed to act.  The press, too, was quick to publish as much sordid detail as was possible, given the limits imposed by the victims' juvenile status, though since I was then in an insular, small town, anonymity was a fiction.  To read this article is heartening: if the medical professionals who formerly diagnosed shaken baby syndrome without questioning any other possible etiology take pause, this is a good thing.  Child abuse is a terrible thing; to be wrongly accused of it, even worse.

The question of "what," head trauma, for instance, may be obvious to a physician, although I am not sure that there is no controversy.

The "how" - medical condition, accidental fall, or shaking, or beating - and the "who" and the "when" make the problem a lot sketchier.

Assuming based on a physician's exam that the nanny did it the nursery with a good shaking is more an outcome from Clue than obvious trial evidence.
Controversy exists when the trial cases use "what" to prove "who" and "how."

What the writer is saying is that the syndrome definitely exists. I have seen enough cases to last a lifetime, with abusers who admit their guilt openly to me before even police involvement. I can tell you that for myself, and the other doctors I work with, if there is not a good story for abuse, or other markers thereof, we exhaustively consider other possibilities such as bleeding disorders or genetic disorders, typically involving multiple specialists in these areas, because this is not a diagnosis you want to mistakenly make. Besides the obvious legal ramifications, it leaves the child patient vulnerable to further damage by misdiagnosis. Many times the diagnosis remains unclear, and we just live with that uncertainty.

However, there is a big difference between acknowledging that other factors can cause syndromes that look like shaken baby, and should be ruled out, and stating, as many commentators here have, that shaken baby syndrome does not exist. The headline is overly inflammatory. There is no reasonable debate that shaken baby syndrome in general exists. The question, about whether to apply it to a particular case or not, is up for debate and should be always considered according to the particulars.
Here we go - more bunkum to try to blame vaccines for everything.

As a physician frequently involved in the diagnosis of such syndromes I find this article to be poorly written at best. There is no debate in the medical community about this diagnosis. Succeeding in tracking down one quack with an odd opinion does not an article or journalism make.
This article for example, comments that there have been many cases in which charges were dropped or overturned involving the shaken baby syndrome. I fail to understand the relevance of that. It is possible for physicians to conclude through evidence that shows a number of traumatic injuries to the baby of varying ages that the baby has been subject to repeated trauma. Of course the CT scan does not tell us who did it. The police and prosecutors have to figure that out. How on earth does the fact that a certain percentage of prosecutions of persons for abuse do not result in a guilty verdict suggest that the baby was not abused in the first place? There's just no logic to this fluff piece.

To Donald Seekins: That Africans sold other Africans into slavery does not absolve Europeans and European Americans of permanently linking race with slavery. In no other culture was it assumed that the color of ones skin determined ones freedom. I don't believe there's another culture in which slaves were bred, and the offspring of any slave was determined to be the property of the slaveholder. When you have a culture where people are forbidden under pain of death not to learn to read (or to teach a slave to read), where the most defiant members of a group were punished and often put to death, where physical strength was prized above all, you have created a situation whose legacy will linger for centuries. It's time for white people (I am one) to stop smirking and blaming others for what our ancestors created and from whose values we still benefit.

But it isn't relevant to the discussion at hand. Facing slavery in America does not require us to say that whites are unusual in comparison to other human beings. It only requires us to say what actually happened here. That the creation of race in order to enslave and the brutality that occurred and the caste system with all its oppressions it created. And that great evil was done.

That's it. That other people do it to is irrelevant to the point. It is like teaching the Holocaust and saying but lots of people commit genocide (even against the Jews).Yes, but that doesn't change a single fact about the Holocaust.

The process that was done to make enslaved Africans socially dead so that it seemed ok to enslave them has been done many times before (See Orlando Patterson's Slavery and Social Death) but that doesn't change the fact that it was done here, and done thoroughly and the consequences of that process are still being felt by African-Americans today.

This really isn't as hard to cope with as my fellow white Americans are making it out to be.

" . . . one white woman’s sole contribution to the discussion last year was to ask with a smirk whether Africans sold other Africans to European dealers."

She may have smirked, but in fact the sale of Africans by Africans to whites took place on a very large scale. By challenging "white privilege," historians should not ignore the fact that all races have been oppressively brutal to people who were weaker than themselves.

Theoretically speaking, subarachnoid hemorrhage alone could cause a spike in blood pressure that could in turn cause retinal hemorrhages and cerebral edema. So the second and third of the "triad" are not completely independent of the first. And we all know subarachnoid hemorrhage has many possible causes. I'm not saying most times a child presents with the triad it isn't abuse. It almost certainly is. But it's not a certainty, and it worries me when medical professionals are so sure of what they know, because what they know is inherently limited.

I suspect that most US historians do the work of contextualizing North American slavery. You're right that students would find slavery has existed in many forms, in many places, and many time periods. You're also right that the cast of actors would be what we today consider diverse. But students also have to confront what made US slavery unique in the modern world:

*The south was a slave society and not a society with slaves. That is, economics, politics, and thought -- in short the ideology of the antebellum South -- was predicated on the defense and extension of slavery

*Americans, southerners and northerners alike, increasingly justified the mass enslavement of people of African descent as natural. By the 19th century this justification relied on scientific explanations, creating what we today call race.

*Slavery was fundamental to US westward expansion, the growth of capitalism, and of industry

*Finally, US Southerners were one of the few groups of slaveholders to argue that slavery was a positive good, an argument they continued to advance as wide swaths of the world embraced liberal free labor

Making students aware of these differences, especially the entrenchment of slavery, is not advancing a political agenda. It's just good history, the cost of which is making students uncomfortable.

I have always been intrigue with history.....ALL history.  I also have been a believer that in teaching history..it should be taught across the board. It should never to be meant for one sided. I think with enough history....when teaching slavery....it should include Egyptian and others as described. Then students will see a bigger picture. I feel that when I was school age with learning, I was just a sponge and just soaked up everything. Looking back now I now play catch up. I read and cross reference for truth....because my knowledge has left a lot of holes in my learning.

No other slavery system in history has generated more wealth and power than the West's African slave trade.  It's like comparing Walmart with a mom and pop shop.  So, yes, study other slave systems, but be objective about scope, power and legacy.

It all depends on how you approach the subject, and from what perspective. I would suggest that students take World History before they take American History, and that they learn about Egyptian slavery, Greek and Roman slavery, slavery in the Islamic world, slavery in Southeast Asia and other manifestations of this all-too-common historical phenomenon before embarking on the study of (North) American slavery. In that way, they will come to see that "our" history of slavery is not necessarily unique, and that "people of color" have been as historically responsible for the cruelties of slavery as "white people." Studying history with a measure of objectivity may prevent it from being hijacked by people with a - however sympathetic or understandable - political agenda.

I would say that paying for good grades doesn't make sense because the reward comes too late after the action. Grades come out only a few times a year. Doing well on a spelling test is something that should be greeted with celebration immediately or the impact of the reward is lost. Unless you are planning to pay for each success money is a poor options.

My mother, on the other hand, bought into the paying for grades and so I allowed it early on. The problem, I have a very motivated child, who does not need monetary rewards. He does it for the love of learning (maybe because I cheer him on for his hard work immediately). Unfortunately, my mother had no idea what she was getting herself into when she promised $20 per A in 1st grade. Now in high school he has a 4.0 with 7 periods of classes and report cards 4 times a year. My mother had to stop with the monetary rewards because it got too expensive!

I completely agree with Mike's suggestion:  Don't add sugar to your borscht recipe, whether you make this one or another!  Savor the taste of the beets in all their ruby glory, no processed sugar needed.

Beets are a source of sugar that is actually healthy so the added sugar does not make sense. To make the soup even healthier cut up small pieces of Wakame seaweed and simmer with the beets and garlic. The Wakame, like all sea vegetables, will enrich the flavor and is a great source of minerals.
